title: Experts have revealed the REAL cause of mumbling problems on BBC - and it isn't the shows
text:

She said: “I found it really offensive because when it left the editing suite it was absolutely fine. 
“I don’t think it’s rubbish that people can’t hear it, I think it is about your equipment rather than what we do. If you’ve got a big flat-screen TV and put it up against a wall, it muffles the sound.” 
But speaking in the wake of the latest row over inaudible dialogue, in Sunday night’s SS-GB on BBC1, Clark said that often the actors were not blameless. Read More SS-GB blasted by viewers who say mumbling actors ruined Nazi drama as BBC receives 100 complaints Sarah Lancashire as Catherine Cawood in Happy Valley (Photo: PA) 
He pointed to an increased trend among young actors “for what they call ‘realism’ and what we call ‘unintelligible’.” 
Yesterday it emerged that SS-GB’s production company Sid Gentle Films, which also makes The Durrells for ITV , had met all the sound criteria set by the BBC. “It was delivered meeting all the specified requirements,” said one source. 
The second episode will be re-edited this week in a bid to make the sound crisper for viewers this weekend. 
Mumbling in dramas seems to blight the BBC far more than the commercial channels. Mark Rylance in Wolf Hall (Photo: BBC) 
Last year BBC content director Charlotte Moore said producers had been issued with “a new set of guidelines” in a bid to tackle the problem. 
But she admitted they were struggling to find the cause of the problem, which also affected Taboo earlier this year. “It is incredibly hard to get to the bottom of where things go wrong,” she said. “It is often several different problems coming together.”
